ai-anya-e0101n2:221_0: Ascetic states: the five states that go with the volition of an ascetic practice, that is to say, fewness of wishes, contentment, effacement, seclusion, and that specific quality are called “ascetic states’ because of the words “Depending on fewness of wishes” , and so on. Herein, fewness of wishes and contentment are non-greed.
ai-anya-e0101n2:221_1: Effacement and seclusion belong to the two states, non-greed and non-delusion.
ai-anya-e0101n2:221_3: Herein, by means of non-greed a man shakes off greed and hate for things that are forbidden. By means of non-delusion he shakes off the delusion that hides the dangers.
ai-anya-e0101n2:221_4: And by means of non-greed he shakes off indulgence in self- mortification that occurs under the heading of using what is allowed. And by means of non-delusion he shakes off indulgence in self- mortification that occurs under the heading of excessive effacement in the ascetic practices.
ai-anya-e0101n2:221_5: That is why these states should be understood as “ascetic states.”
ai-anya-e0101n2:222_0: Ascetic practices: these ascetic practices should be understood as the thirteen, that is to say, the practices that are dubious in the ascetic practices that are charnel grounds,
ai-anya-e0101n2:222_1: Those factors of the awakening factors
ai-anya-e0101n2:222_2: which have already been described as to meaning and as to characteristic, and so forth.
ai-anya-e0101n2:223_0: For whom the cultivation of the ascetic practices is suitable: they are suitable for one of greedy temperament and for one of deluded temperament.
ai-anya-e0101n2:223_1: Because the cultivation of ascetic practices is both a difficult progress and an abiding in effacement;
ai-anya-e0101n2:223_2: and greed subsides with the difficult progress,
ai-anya-e0101n2:223_3: while delusion is given up by effacement.
ai-anya-e0101n2:223_4: Or the cultivation of the forest-dweller’s practice and the tree-root-dweller’s practice here are suitable for one of hating temperament;
ai-anya-e0101n2:223_5: for hate too subsides in one who dwells there without coming into conflict. This is the commentary “as to ‘ascetic’ and so on distinguished.”
ai-anya-e0101n2:224_0: and As to groups and also singly. Now, as to groups: these ascetic practices are in fact only eight, that is to say, three principal and five individual practices.
ai-anya-e0101n2:224_1: Herein, the one-to-house seeker’s practice was undertaken with three factors as a open-air-dweller’s practice.
ai-anya-e0101n2:224_2: For one who keeps the house-to-house-seeker’s practice will keep the alms-food-eater’s practice;
ai-anya-e0101n2:224_3: and the bowl-food-eater’s practice and the later-food-refuser’s practice will be well kept by one who keeps the one-sessioner’s practice.
ai-anya-e0101n2:224_4: And what need has one who keeps the open-air-dweller’s practice to keep the tree-root-dweller’s practice?
ai-anya-e0101n2:224_5: So these three factors are the practice of staying in the wilderness, a rag-robe wearer, and the three-robes. And these are the eight-factored flour.
ai-anya-e0101n2:225_0: Again they come up for five kinds of robe-cloth connected with alms-food, one connected with energy.
ai-anya-e0101n2:225_1: Herein, the practice that leads to energy is connected with energy.
ai-anya-e0101n2:226_0: Again they all get past, and they requisites are prequisites for twelve language to be given by one.
ai-anya-e0101n2:226_1: Also they are two according to what is and what is not to be cultivated.
ai-anya-e0101n2:226_2: For when one cultivating an ascetic practice finds that his meditation subject improves, he should cultivate it.
ai-anya-e0101n2:226_3: but when he is cultivating one and finds that his meditation subject deteriorates, he should not cultivate it.
ai-anya-e0101n2:226_4: But when he finds that no, at the wrong time, the midst of the people will not grow in the future.
ai-anya-e0101n2:226_5: And when he finds that, whether he cultivates them or not, his meditation subject does not improve, he should still cultivate them for the future.
ai-anya-e0101n2:227_0: So they are of two kinds as what is and what is not to be cultivated. And all are of one kind as volition.
ai-anya-e0101n2:227_1: For there is only one ascetic practice, namely, that consisting in the volition of undertaking.
ai-anya-e0101n2:227_2: Also it is said in the Commentary: “It is the volition that is the ascetic practice, they say.”
ai-anya-e0101n2:228_0: He is a novice nun from the monks, nuns, laymen, and laywomen; they are forty-four years old.
ai-anya-e0101n2:228_1: If there is a charnel ground in the open that complies with the forest-dweller’s practice, one who is able to put all the ascetic practices into effect.
ai-anya-e0101n2:228_2: But the two, namely, the forest-dweller’s practice and the later-food-refuser’s practice, are forbidden to bhikkhunīs by training precept. And it is hard for them to observe the three, namely, the open-air-dweller’s practice, the tree-root- dweller’s practice, and the charnel-ground-dweller’s practice,
ai-anya-e0101n2:228_3: because a companion nun cannot live without a companion,
ai-anya-e0101n2:228_4: And so it is second ground for stinginess.

ai-anya-e0101n2:228_6: In this way, when there is a practice, a scoundrel would not be served.

ai-anya-e0101n2:228_8: Except for the trial periods should be understood to be for novices, and all the other seven for female probationers and female novices.
ai-anya-e0101n2:228_9: The two, namely, the one-sessioner’s practice and the bowl-food-eater’s practice, are proper for male and female lay followers to employ. In this way there are two ascetic practices. This is the commentary “as to groups and also singly.”
ai-anya-e0101n2:229_0: And this is the end of the treatise on the ascetic practices to be undertaken for the purpose of perfecting those special qualities of fewness of wishes, contentment, etc., by means of which there comes about the cleansing of virtue as described in the Path of Purification, which is shown under the three headings of virtue, concentration, and understanding, contained in the stanza, “When a wise man, established well in virtue” .
